text: Generates curves to use as trails for the
This node is a higher level tool to quickly generate pyro trail paths. It takes the incoming points and generates a cloud of points around them using the
node to generate the paths based on the scattered points, without the need of any particle simulation. If no input is provided, it creates trails shooting out from to the origin.
If you dive inside this node, some of the attributes can be changed on the generated points before they are used to generate the paths.
Each point on the curve stores a
on the first point of each curve, and increases with each consecutive point on the curve, indicating the position of the projectile on the path at a given time.
This attribute is used by the
node, so it must be preserved.

for each path, you must offset its value if your timeline starts at a frame other than

attribute to slow down or speed up the projectile along its trajectory. For example, multiplying
values by 2 will uniformly slow down the flight.
This node also creates a float type primitive attribute called
, which stores the frame number when the projectile is launched on the path. When
stores values other than 1, it must be combined with the
will automatically do this combination if a primitive
attribute is found on the curves, making sure the trail source starts at the right time.

It is possible to generate trails for multiple bursts with one node. By default, all bursts will have the same properties, as set by the node’s parameters (such as
, etc.). To vary these properties for each burst, select the

option on the menu next to the corresponding parameter. This will use a different random value in the provided range for each input point. These generated random numbers are seeded with point numbers by default. To use a custom integer attribute instead, set
. This will ensure that randomized properties will remain the same for an input point even if points are shuffled or removed from the input, provided value of the
You can also manually override parameter values with attributes. For example, if the input geometry has a
point attribute, its values can be used instead of the global
. This allows you to finely control the size of each burst. To do this, the menu next to the corresponding parameter must also be set to
Parameters that can be controlled by point attributes are listed in the table below.

This node is not able to handle colliders to the same level as a particle simulation. However, a basic clipping and a collision system has been created to handle simple use-cases. If you need more advanced collision handling, you need to run a particle simulation to obtain ballistic paths.
To make a particle simulation with the generated trail paths, do the following.
node and change its parameters to match this node.
This will generate a particle simulation setup that is converted into pyro trails.
The subset of the input geometry points to use for point cloud generation. Leave this blank to use all points.
to visualize where trails can originate. This is determined by
This menu lets you run some simple scripted setups to help with the most common tasks.
node with a single point that is ready to be positioned where you need the explosion to happen.
node upstream that helps you visualize the
point attribute over time to see when each input point is triggered.
node to generate source points from the trails. These points can be rasterized into volumes that can serve as sources for a pyro simulation.

. This is useful if you want all scatter properties to be controlled by the parameter interface.

Bursts usually disappear soon after their creation, which can makes it difficult to visualize them together with the trails. Turn this on to see pyro bursts as guides while displaying this node to help synchronize the animation of different elements. It can accept a white-space separated list of
When multiple input points are used for one explosion by the

, you usually only need one input point to generate the trails. Enabling this allows you to fuse all incoming points into one or fuse them together by matching attribute values of a custom attribute. When points are fused together, the
point attribute will be set to the minimum value of all fused point values, while direction (
No points will be fused together, all points will contribute to generate trails.
All incoming points will be fused to a single point that will be used for trail generation.
Points that have the same value for
will be fused into a single source.
The attribute to control which points will be fused together. To fuse points together, they have to have the same attribute value. This must be an integer attribute.
Controls how the random selection is seeded for parameters that are using
. Topology changes on the input geometry can shift element numbers, causing a different random selection to be used.
lets you provide an integer attribute to make sure the random value is not dependent on element order.

randomization button on the right side of this parameter to randomize the value per incoming element. This will create/select a corresponding attribute adjust node to give you greater control over the parameter’s value.
The integer type attribute to use for random selection for parameters that are using
The trails can be launched in a spherical shape around the incoming points or along the burst’s direction (as set by
if you want trails launching from the center of the explosion or
when you want trails shooting out from the rising mushroom cloud.
The starting size of the burst in which trails will be launched. A value of
means the diameter of the burst is roughly 1 unit.

randomization button on the right side of this parameter to randomize the value per incoming element. This will create/select a corresponding attribute adjust node to give you greater control over the parameter’s value.
attribute by this amount when the menu is set to
. This allows you to quickly scale your burst without adjusting the attribute values.
Sets the maximum allowed variation. Sizes will be between
Controls the random selection for variation. Change this value if the current variation is undesirable.
The direction of the burst. You can change the direction to make the trails come out from the side of a building, for example.
, this vector also corresponds to spread angle of
controls the line that shoots out trails.

Sets the maximum allowed variation in degrees. The varied direction will spread out in a cone shape from
Controls the random selection for variation. Change this value if the current variation is undesirable.
Controls the random scattering of starting points for trails. Change this value to obtain different trails for the same set of shape parameters.
The number of trails to generate per input point. Increase this parameter to create more trails.

Azimuth controls how trails are generated around the burst direction (as set by
), therefore you can use it to generate trails only on a desired side of the explosion. By default, the value of
will create trails on the +X axis and they are rotated around the burst direction vector counter-clockwise as the value increases.

randomization button on the right side of this parameter to randomize the value per incoming element. This will create/select a corresponding attribute adjust node to give you greater control over the parameter’s value.
Sets the maximum allowed variation in degrees. The variation will be from
Controls the random selection for variation. Change this value if the current variation is undesirable.
Azimuth controls how trails are generated around the burst direction (as set by
), therefore you can use it to generate trails only on a desired side of the explosion. Increasing this value will spread out the trails from the
around the burst direction both clockwise and counter-clockwise. The value of
means that trails will be created all around the burst direction.

randomization button on the right side of this parameter to randomize the value per incoming element. This will create/select a corresponding attribute adjust node to give you greater control over the parameter’s value.
Sets the maximum allowed variation in degrees. The generated values will be between
Controls the random selection for variation. Change this value if the current variation is undesirable.
Removes some of the trails based on a noise pattern. Use this to create more interesting trail patterns. When this checkbox is turned on,
might need to be increased to compensate for the removed trails.
Controls base feature size of the generated noise. The value applies to each axis.
The offset along the Y-axis. Change this value if the current noise pattern is undesirable.
The scale increment between iterations of fractal noise. The higher the value, the larger the

Sets the length (magnitude) of the launch velocity for the trails. Increase this to make the trails shoot out faster and cover larger distances during their life time.

of the paths for points further away from the center, when
. The spread angle refers to the angle between the burst’s direction (as set by
) and a path’s starting velocity vector. Therefore, a spread angle of
will result in a path that’s aimed in the burst’s direction, and a spread angle of
will result in a path that starts out perpendicular to the burst’s direction. In the common case of
will produce paths that are shooting out horizontally at the top of the emission line. Use the

button to quickly randomize the value per trail.
    The spread angle for the starting point of a path is fully determined by its distance to the burst center along the direction. When this distance is at

, respectively. The spread angle is linearly interpolated for distances between them.

Sets the maximum allowed variation in degrees. The generated values will be between
Controls the random selection for variation. Change this value if the current variation is undesirable.
When this checkbox is turned on, it changes the direction of the trails based on a noise pattern. Use this to randomize and create more variation in the trail directions.
Sets the strength of the noise. Higher values will create more variation between the trails.
Controls base feature size of the generated noise. The value applies to each axis.
The offset along the Y-axis. Change this value if the current noise pattern is undesirable.
The scale increment between iterations of fractal noise. The higher the value, the larger the

When this checkbox is turned on, it changes the length (magnitude) of the launch velocity for the trails based on a noise pattern. Increasing launch velocity makes the trails shoot out faster and cover more distance during their lifetime.
Sets how much of the launch velocity can be scaled down from its original length. The value of
means, that no velocities will be shorter than their original length.
Sets how much of the launch velocity can be scaled up from it’s original length. The value of
means, that no velocities will be longer than their original length.
Controls base feature size of the generated noise. The value applies to each axis.
The offset along the Y-axis. Change this value if the current noise pattern is undesirable.
The scale increment between iterations of fractal noise. The higher the value, the larger the
Limits the magnitude of the launch velocity. Use it to limit the minimum or the maximum launch speeds.
Sets the air resistance for the projectiles. Higher values will result in faster loss of energy and shorter travel distance. A
of zero will produce a symmetric arc.

randomization button on the right side of this parameter to randomize the value per incoming element. This will create/select a corresponding attribute adjust node to give you greater control over the parameter’s value.
Sets the maximum allowed variation. Drag values will fall between
Controls the random selection for variation. Change this value if the current variation is undesirable.
Sets the mass for the projectile. Higher values will cause the projectile to more strongly resist drag and travel a longer distance.

randomization button on the right side of this parameter to randomize the value per incoming element. This will create/select a corresponding attribute adjust node to give you greater control over the parameter’s value.
Sets the maximum allowed variation. Projectile masses will be between
Controls the random selection for variation. Change this value if the current variation is undesirable.
Sets the force that attracts the projectile towards the ground. Set all components to zero if you want straight trails, which are not affected by gravity.

The number of divisions in the path for every second of time.  Usually
    one wants a division per frame, thus this is often related to your
    frames per second.

Sets how many times to divide the trail into further segments. The larger the number, the more points will be created for each curve to help with post-deformations. You do not need to change this parameter from the default, if you do not intend to apply any post-deformation.
primitive attribute on the generated curves to indicate when each trail is to start. This parameter can be used to control timing of the projectiles. The
attribute gets set on the incoming points before the trails are seeded; therefore, all points created from the same input point will have the same start frame. Use

to vary the start frame per scattered point. Use the button to the right of this parameter to visualize start frames for scattered points; grey points haven’t triggered at the current frame, while red ones have.
point attribute is used to tell where the projectile is on the path at a given time, the
following this node. Therefore you must make sure to preserve this attribute. For more information, see

randomization button on the right side of this parameter to randomize the value per incoming element. This will create/select a corresponding attribute adjust node to give you greater control over the parameter’s value.
When this is turned on, it colors trails that have not started as grey, and already started trails as red.
attribute by this amount when the menu is set to
. This allows you to quickly change the
attribute without needing to adjust the attribute value. This value sets
on the incoming points before the trails are generated, so all paths created from the same input point will have the same start frame.
Sets the maximum allowed variation. The generated values will cover the range from
Controls the random selection for variation. Change this value if the current variation is undesirable.

Sets the maximum allowed start frame offset for each trail. You need to turn this on to vary the start frames for trails generated from the same input point. This will set the offset value as unit of frames, when you only need couple of frames as offset. However, if you need an offset longer than a few seconds, using
to start the trails gradually along the burst’s direction (as set by
Sets the maximum allowed start frame offset extension for each trail as unit of time. It might be easier to provide the offset as unit of time when the trails need to live longer than a few seconds.
Controls the random selection for variation. Change this value if the current variation is undesirable.

, this ramp allows you to start the trails that are closer to the burst center before ones that are further away. The left side of the ramp applies to trails that are the closest to the burst center, while the right side is for trails that are the furthest. When the ramp’s value is set to
Sets the length of the trails in frames. Higher values produce longer trails.

randomization button on the right side of this parameter to randomize the value per incoming element. This will create/select a corresponding attribute adjust node to give you greater control over the parameter’s value.
Sets the length of the trails in seconds. Higher values produce longer trails.
Sets the maximum allowed variation for

. The generated
        values will be between
Controls the random selection for variation. Change this value if the current variation is undesirable.
Sets how fast the projectile is moving on the trail path. Lowering this value will make the projectiles move slower, while increasing this value will make them move faster.

randomization button on the right side of this parameter to randomize the value per incoming element. This will create/select a corresponding attribute adjust node to give you greater control over the parameter’s value.
Sets the maximum allowed variation for
. The generated scales will be between
Controls the random selection for variation. Change this value if the current variation is undesirable.
Turning on this checkbox lets you clip projectiles that fall below

The height to use for clipping. Trajectories will terminate once the Y coordinate
    falls below this value.
Turns on a basic collision detection system for the path to collide with objects.
The SOP path to the geometry the projectile paths need to collide with. If the geometry contains a
primitive attribute that is set to
, trajectories will terminate when they hit that primitive; otherwise, they will bounce and continue.

The maximum number of allowed bounces for projectile paths. After this
    number of bounces, the path will terminate. Set this to

, if you want to
    eliminate all projectiles on the first collision hit.

Specifies what fraction of the original speed is maintained on collision in
    the direction of the collision normal. A value of

will simply reverse this
    normal component of velocity, whereas smaller values will also reduce it.
    A value of
will kill the projectile upon collision.
Specifies what fraction of the original speed is maintained in the tangential plane of the collision. A value of
will leave the tangential velocity unaffected; a value of
will eliminate the tangential component of velocity after the collision.
Copies custom created point attributes from the input points to the generated trails. This will ignore copying all internally used attributes.
Only copy attributes whose names match this pattern. The default
copies all attributes. This will ignore copying all internally used attributes.
When this checkbox is turned on, attributes will be promoted from input points to curve primitives that they generate.
The primitive attribute storing a unique id attribute for each generated path.
The primitive attribute storing the index number of the generated trails.
The primitive attribute storing length of the velocity vector at the start of each trail.
The primitive attribute storing the time when the trail ends.
When this checkbox is turned on, the
primitive attribute will be created to store the value used by the

title: Pyro Trail Path
